primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: God/Jesus provides cosmic and material abundance (Bread of Life) to satisfy the hunger of all living things, countering the false narrative of scarcity.

tekstueel_bewijs: Jesus announces that he is the Bread of Life
He took five loaves... and distributed them
You open your hand, satisfying the desire of every living thing
satisfaction of all who are hungry
God who gives seed to the sower and bread to the eater

ontvanger.identificatie: All creatures / The hungry crowd / The Hearer
tekstueel_bewijs: The eyes of all look to you
distributed them to those who were seated
ontvanger.positie_hoorder: Receiver (initially), then challenged to become Subject of the secondary program.

helper.identificatie: Gratitude / Eucharist / Holy Juices of Creation
tekstueel_bewijs: had the holy juices of creation
Pharaoh is a metaphor... for those who have succumbed to the notion of scarcity
this anxiety about scarcity is all around us
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Scarcity is presented as a systemic, demonic 'ideology' that governs world structures and human hearts.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The believer must move from an ideology of scarcity to an ideology of abundance and seek justice.
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Hearer ('We')
secundair_narratief_programma.object: Justice / Trust / Moving from scarcity to abundance
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The abundance of God (Program 1) is the ground that makes the 'hard work' of the move (Program 2) possible.

actantieel_schema_visualisatie.zender_naar_ontvanger: Creator God → Bread of Life → All Creatures

voorbeelden_god_subject: Jesus announces that he is the Bread of Life
God has so ordered summer and winter
He fulfills the desire of all who fear him
voorbeelden_mens_subject: We have largely accepted the notion of scarcity
It is the project of our faith to move our lives

voorbeelden: Dominant culture does not want us to ask questions
To what extent do we trust God’s bread?
The narrator recognizes that what made the abundance possible
move our lives from an ideology of scarcity... It is hard work

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon focuses on shifting the 'will' and 'trust' of the hearer from one system of value (scarcity) to another (abundance).

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: Moves from S1 (Biblical texts) to S2 (Pharaoh/Modern culture) to ~S2 (The Eucharist/Communion) as the bridge back to S1.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: The Eucharist is the 'interruption' of scarcity that allows for the return to abundance.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High; scarcity is treated as a systemic 'bread of affliction'.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: While there is a strong ethical call, it is rooted in the ontological reality of God's abundance. God is the primary Subject of the miracles and the cosmic order.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: It is hard work for all of us to make this move

indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: God’s got the whole world in God’s hand. And now it is open.

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: Elisha and Jesus are not presented as moral examples to follow, but as 'agents of abundance' revealing God's character.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: Theocentric: God acts through these figures to provide for the needy.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Relief from anxiety; call to social awareness.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Soteriology is tied to creation and providence (God as sustainer).

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the biblical 'abundance' to the systemic 'scarcity' is logically and narratively tight.
spanning_punten: The tension between 'God provides for all' and the reality that 'the poor have no bread'.

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: When we receive the bread of Jesus we enter a zone of generosity.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: Implicit in the 'holy juices of creation'.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Sin is the 'ideology of scarcity'—a systemic blindness to God's grace.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The sermon successfully maintains God as the Subject of abundance, but shifts the Subject to 'Us' when discussing the 'move' away from scarcity.

subject_herpositionering.huidige_probleem: The 'move' from scarcity to abundance is described as human 'hard work'.
subject_herpositionering.voorgestelde_herpositionering: Frame the 'move' as a work of the Spirit or the 'Bread' itself transforming the eater.
subject_herpositionering.voorbeeld_revisie: Instead of 'It is hard work for us to make this move,' use 'The Bread of Life itself moves us from the grip of scarcity.'

identificatie_herstel.strategie: Keep the hearer as the one whose eyes 'look to God'.

modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Emphasize that the Eucharist gives the *power* to be generous, not just the *desire*.

tegenstander_intensivering.theologische_rationale: The opponent is already well-defined as a spiritual/political power.

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: A powerful theocentric sermon that avoids moralism by grounding ethics in the character of the Creator.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: Rhetorical analysis would focus on the 'communist' shock-value; Greimas shows that 'communist' is actually an actantial role (asking about the Sender/Receiver relationship).
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains the 12 baskets; Greimas explains the 12 baskets as the 'Object' of abundance proving the 'Subject's' competence.
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that the sermon's power comes from the clash between two 'Senders': God (Abundance) vs. Pharaoh (Scarcity).

appendices.notities: The sermon uses the 'Bread of Life' as a bridge between physical sustenance and spiritual trust.
